title: Senior Al-Qaeda commander Asim Omar killed in US raid on Taliban
text:
Top Al-Qaeda commander Asim Omar has been killed following joint US-Afghanistan airstrikes on a Taliban compound in the Helmand province of Afghanistan

WARNING: GRAPHIC CONTENT

One of terrorist group Al-Qaeda’s most senior commanders has been killed on a joint US-Afghanistan raid.

Asim Omar was killed alongside six other terrorists during the raid on the Taliban in Afghanistan’s Helmand province on September 23, it was revealed on Tuesday.

Omar worked as head of operations for the terror outfit’s South Asia division, and was embedded with Taliban fighters when he was wiped out.

Also killed was courier to Al-Qaeda leader Ayma Al-Zawahiri and 22 other Taliban fighters, Afghanistan’s National Directorate for Security said.

A large warehouse of supplies and equipment was obliterated in the same air strike.

A photo appearing to show Asim Omar’s dead body emerged after he was killed in a US-Afghan joint air strike

A spokesman explained: ‘They had been embedded inside the Taliban compound in the Taliban stronghold of Musa Qala.

Those strikes left 12 others wounded and requiring hospital treatment in Helamd capital Lashkar gah, MailOnline reported.

The number of civilians killed by US and Afghan forces has now surpassed those killed by the Taliban and other insurgent groups, a United Nations report has revealed.

That conflict was started by then-President George W Bush weeks after Al-Qaeda successfully launched the September 11 2001 terror attacks on the United States, killing 2,977 people.

Al-Qaeda founder Osama bin Laden, who masterminded the 9/11 attacks, was killed by US special forces during a raid of his Pakistan compound in 2011.

Bin laden’s son Hamza, who followed his father into Al-Qaeda, was killed during a US counterterrorism operation sometime after Donald Trump became president.

Further details of that operation have never been released.
description: Asim Omar was killed alongside six other terrorists and 22 Taliban fighters during air strikes on Afghanistan's Helmand province
